questions.text: Correct about given vacutainer is?
Compare the normality of 2 mM of HCI and 1 mM of H2SO4:
questions.solution:
Normality = Molarity X No. of H+ ions per molecule

So, for 2 mM HCl, N= 2mM X 1 = 2 mN

For 1 mM H2SO4, N= 1 mM X 2= 2 mN

questions.text: CO2 elimination = 200, O2 consumed = 250, calculate respiratory quotient:
questions.solution: RQ = (CO2 elimination)/ (O2 consumed)

choices.text: Volume of Serum passing through kidney in 24 hour

questions.text: Which value is not required to measure Creatinine Clearance?
Intercellular communication in eukaryotic cells is mediated by:
questions.solution: Proposed mechanisms for the formation and production of exosomes and microvesicles via exocytosis (exosome) and membrane budding (microvesicle) from a source cell. Vesicles produced in the multivesicular body (MVB) can be exocytosed following fusion with the plasma membrane as shown, or budded into the extracellular space. All of these processes involve the collection of proteins, lipids, and signaling molecules previously implicated in exocytosis and budding (not shown). Once released from the source cell, the resulting exosomes and/or microvesicles locate their target cell, and following the types of vesicle target cell interactions shown, release their contents (see Black arrows within the target cell). Different vesicles have been shown to contain RNA (mRNA, miRNA, lncRNA; and DNA, Specific bioactive proteins and lipids; antigens; and biologically active small molecules. Importantly, extracellular vesicles have been shown to have both positive and negative biologic effects on target cells in both normal and pathologic states.

questions.text: Maximum buffering capacity of a buffer is at pH - (NE-2016-3)
questions.solution:
Henderson-Hasselbalch equation:

pH =pK +log [Base] /[Acid]

As per this equation, best buffering action will be when concentrations of base and acid are equal, meaning when target pH=pK.

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below: pH= 7.2, HCO3=10 mEq/L, PCO2=30 mmHg. This exemplifies which of the following disorder?
questions.solution: Davenport Diagram

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with tachypnea and mental confusion. Blood glucose level is 350 mg/dl, pH=7.0. Urine shows presence of ketone bodies. What is the most likely acid base disorder?
questions.solution: Diabetic ketoacidosis is a type of Metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Subcellular organelles with their respective marker enzymes are all except:
Which of following does not occur in mitochondria?
Which of the following enzyme dysfunction leads to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase lead to Lactic Acidosis:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the —SH groups of lipoic acid.
  • dietary deficiency of thiamin:
    • Many alcoholics are thiamin-deficient (both because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamin absorption
  • inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.text: Thiamine is a cofactor for all of the following enzymes except?
questions.solution:
Thiamine is a cofactor for :

  • Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH)
  • Kreb cycle (alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase)
  • HMP shunt (Transketolase)
  • Branch Chain AA Metabolism (Branched Chain ketoacid ddehydrogenase)

questions.text: A 56 year old homeless man presents to ER with increased fatigability and exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows significant lower extremity edema and decreased sensation over the ankles and feet. Further evaluation reveals cardiac dilation and increased cardiac output. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Beri-Beri, due to Thiamine deficiency:

  • Dry Beri Beri:-
    • It involves CNS in the form of paresthesia, general weakness, atrophy, foot and wrist drop.
  • Wet Beri Beri:-
    • It involves CVS in the form of palpitation, tachycardia, AR, edema, high cardiac output failure
  • Acute/Infant Beri Beri:-
    • Seen in those infants whose mothers milk is deficient in B1

questions.text: A middle aged woman presents with fissures in mouth tingling sensation, peripheral neuropathy. Investigation showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency causes this?
questions.solution:
Ariboflavinosis results in stomatitis:

  • painful red tongue with sore throat
  • chapped and fissured lips (cheilosis)
  • inflammation of the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis)
  • normochromic normocytic anemia
  • Riboflavin level monitored by measuring activity of erythrocyte Glutathione Reductase

questions.text: Which vitamin is required for glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
• Pyridoxine, required (in the form of Pyridoxal phosphate) as a cofactor for :
    • Catecholamines, serotonin, GABA
    • Transamination
    • Deamination
    • Decarboxylation
    • Serine (Serine racemase)
    • Methionine, cysteine ( cystathionine synthase and cystathionase)
    • Selenocysteine Synthesis
    • Tryptophan to Niacin
    • Glycogenolysis
    • Sphingolipids
    • Heme synthesis

questions.text: Vitamin deficiency causing neonatal seizures
questions.solution:
• Pyridoxine-dependent seizure/epilepsy(PDS/PDE) is a recognized cause of intractable seizures in neonates, psychomotor developmental delay, and, sometimes, death in untreated patients
  • Folinic Acid Responsive Epilepsy
  • Biotinidase deficiency causing multiple carboxylase deficiency and presenting with seizures
  • Seizures with vitamin B12 deficiency are rare, but reported.

questions.text: Which enzyme required for Vitamin C synthesis is missing in humans?
questions.solution:
• A vitamin for human beings and other primates, the guinea pig, bats, passeriform birds, most fishes and invertebrates.
    • Enzyme for synthesis missing is L-gulonolactone oxidase.
  • Both ascorbic acid and dehydroascorbic acid have vitamin activity.
  • Deficiency causes Scurvy
  • Acts as anti-oxidant
    • Maintained in reduced state by Glutathione
    • Helps in absorption of iron
  • Has specific roles in the copper-containing hydroxylases and the α-ketoglutarate-linked iron-containing hydroxylases

questions.text: Vitamin that helps in the absorption of iron?
Vitamin D synthesis sequence is?
Vitamin K is needed by which enzyme?
questions.solution: • Dicoumarol is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase; thus, it inhibits vitamin K recycling and causes depletion of active vitamin K in blood.

questions.text: Respiratory quotient after a heavy carbohydrate meal
Galactose and mannose are __________ of each other.
Glucosamines used in the treatment of:
questions.solution: Glucosamines are building blocks of GAGs, present in synovial fluid!

choices.text: Amino sugar and acid are present

questions.text: All of the following are correct about a proteoglycan except:
questions.solution:
• Made of amino sugar & uronic acid
  • Are negatively charged, so hold lot of water.
  • The seven GAGs are:
    • Hyaluronic Acid
    • Chondroitin Sulphate
    • Dermatan Sulphate
    • Keratan Sulphate-I
    • Keratan Sulphate-II
    • Heparin
    • Heparan Sulphate

questions.text: Which of the following is a homopolysaccharide?
questions.solution:
• Homopolysaccharides:
    • Starch: glucose
    • Glycogen: glucose
    • Cellulose: glucose
    • Dextrin: glucose
    • Dextran: glucose
    • Inulin: fructose
    • Chitin: N-acetylglucosamine

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of sugars are both non-reducing?
questions.solution:
• Reducing Sugars:
    • All monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose)
    • Disaccharide: - Lactose, maltose, cellobiose (β-1,4-linkage, glucose + glucose), melibiose (α-1,6- linkage, galactose and glucose)
  • Non-reducing sugars :
    • Disaccharide: - Sucrose, trehalose
      • Trehalose: Both α – glucose with α-1,1- linkage.

questions.text: Following are the tests done for proteins, sugars and ketones. Which will be positive in starvation state in urine?
questions.solution:
Starvation:  Ketones in urine

DKA:    Ketones + Sugar in urine

Chronic Alcohol Inoxication: Ketones in urine

Nephropathy:   Proteins in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is used by RBCs in the fasting state?
questions.solution: RBCs use only glucose in all stages of fed-fasting cycle, since they do not have mitochondria

questions.text: In starvation, thyroid hormone changes do not include:
questions.solution: rT3 is inactive; is elevated when BMR needs to be low.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a glucogenic substrate in humans
questions.solution:
Glucogenic Substrates:

  • Glucogenic Amino Acids all except Lysine, Leucine)
  • Pyruvate
  • Lactate
  • Glycerol
  • Propionate

All these substrates synthesize glucose via Oxaloacetate

questions.text: Method of transport of glucose in the intestine is:
Which of the following enzymes catalyze the irreversible steps of glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Enzymes exclusive for glycolysis:

  • Pyruvate kinase (PK)
  • Phospho-Fructo kinase – 1 (PFK-1)
  • Hexokinase/Glucokinase

questions.text:
Enzymes involved in Gluconeogenesis:
1. Pyruvate kinase
2. PEP Carboxykinase
3. Pyruvate carboxylase
4. Hexokinase
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Enzymes exclusive for Gluconeogenesis:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Phospho-Enol pyruvate carboxy kinase (PEP-CK)
  • Fructose 1,6 – Bisphosphatase
  • Glucose 6-Phosphatase

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is common between glycogenesis and glycogenolysis?
Identify the correct regulatory molecules:
Fastest way to re-generate ATP during exercise?
Anticoagulant used to estimate glucose from a sample sent from PHC is:
Which of the following enzymes is not elevated in fasting?
questions.solution:
Actions of insulin:

  • Increases:
    • Glycolysis
    • Glycogenesis
    • Lipogenesis
    • HMP shunt
    • Amino acid synthesis
    • Cholesterol Synthesis
  • Decreases:
    • Glycogenolysis (Urea cycle goes hand in hand)
    • Lipolysis
    • Gluconeogenesis
  • Inhibits: Ketogenesis

questions.text: Insulin/glucagon ratio decreases in all except:
questions.solution: Change in insulin glucagon ratio has the same trend as the change in insulin concentration!!

choices.text: Increased conversion of Fatty acids to acetyl CoA
Decreased de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver

questions.text: Type 1 DM with fasting BG level of 240mg/dl. Which of the following is most common to occur?
questions.solution: Cholesterol synthesis is regulated not only by the insulin but also by feedback inhibition exerted by the intracellular cholesterol. In Tpe 1 DM, cholesterol returning to liver is low.

choices.text: Can be reduced from multiple branches/ends
Can be stored at multiple site
Can provide glucose as much as needed and when needed for 1 week

questions.text: Glucose is stored in Glycogen form, why?
questions.solution:
Can be reduced from multiple branches/ends

Glycogen is Stored only in Liver, Muscle, Brain

Can barely provide glucose to maintain blood levels for 12-24 hours

questions.text: A female infant appeared normal at birth but developed signs of liver disease one month of age and muscle weakness at 3 months and severe hypoglcemia on early morning awakening. Examination revealed hepatomegaly, laboratory analysis showed ketoacidosis, pH 7.2, increased AST and ALT. Intravenous administration glucagon followed by glucose normalised blood levels, but glucose levels did not rise when glucagon was administered after overnight fasting. Glycogen store was (8%) of wet weight.With the above pictures which of the following enzyme is deficient
questions.solution: Since debranching enzme is not under regulation of glucagon, its deficiency cannot be compensated by adding glucagon!

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents to emergency with a fainting episode during playing football. Blood examination reveals hypoglycemia, raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid & trigylcerides. On examination, liver & kidneys were enlarged. Histopathology of liver shows excess deposits of normally formed glycogen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Fainting episodes due to severe hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia and kidney & liver enlargement are characteristic of GSD-Ia, Von Gierke's Disease

questions.text: A male child is brought to OPD with pain in calf muscles during exercise. Child is fatigable, and has increased glycogen deposit in muscle. What is the enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution: Exclusive Muscle invlovement occurs in GSD-V & VII only.

questions.text: Calories from TPN: 100mg dextrose. 30mg Amino acids 40mg Lipids
questions.solution:
Calories from any meal should be calculated using the following conversion formula:

  • Carbohydrate = 4 cal/mg
  • Amino acid/Protein = 4 cal/mg
  • Lipids/fatty acids = 9 cal/mg

questions.text: Find out the value of LDL, if total cholesterol level is 300 mg/dL, HDL level is 25 mg/dL and triglycerides level is 150 mg/dL?
questions.solution:
Friedwald formula for calculating LDL in lood:

 LDL= Toal Cholesterol – (HDL cholesterol + TG/5)

 TG/5= VLDL, if TG<400mg/dl (So, Friedwald formula should be used only uptil this range!)

questions.text: A 7-year old boy presented with severe abdominal pain. On examination, he had xanthomas. Blood sample was taken for work-up, blood sample had milky appearance of plasma. Which of the following lipoprotein is increased?
questions.solution:
Familial chylomicronemia syndrome presents with fasting triglycerides above 1000 mg/dL generally over 2000 mg/dl in the blood.

Notably, the 'refrigerator test' is performed to diagnose the elevated chylomicron levels in the blood; this method involves evaluating serum samples one day following overnight storage in the refrigerator: if the serum has a creamy supernatant only, then the patient has chylomicronemia (Type 1 hyperlipidemia).

If the infranatant is turbid (lactescent) also then there is an increase in VLDL also like in Type 5 hyperlipidemia which has both increased VLDL and chylomicrons.

The elevated circulating triglycerides in the blood can pose a risk to the pancreas and cause acute pancreatitis, along with their deposition in both the liver and spleen, causing hepatosplenomegaly.

It is also recommended to evaluate the total cholesterol at the time of the highest triglyceride level along with the ratio of the triglyceride to total cholesterol. TG/TC ratio elevation is with circulating chylomicrons and VLDL.

The TG/TC ratio exceeds 5.0 with type1 and types 5 hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: On laboratory investigations in a patient, LDL was highly elevated but the level of LDL receptors was normal. Which of the following is most probable cause?
Chitotriosidase, TRAP and ACE enzymes are elevated. The following histopathological picture is seen on bone marrow examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Crumpled or wrinkled tissue paper appearance: Gaucher Cell, seen in Gaucher’s Disease:

  • Most common lysosomal storage disorder.
  • β-glucosidase, aka, glucocerebrosidase and glucosylceramidase
  • Cherry red spot, mental retardation not seen.
  • Gaucher cells with wrinkled paper appearance.
  • Acute abdominal pain & bone crises.
  • Serum levels of chitotriosidase , ACE, TRAP, & chemokine CCL18/PARK are very high.

questions.text:
Among the following
1. Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole, kcat of an enzyme = 20 s-1
2. Km of an enzyme = 200 nanomole, kcat of an enzyme = 50 s-1
3. Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole, kcat of an enzyme = 200 s-1
4. Km of an enzyme = 4 micromole, kcat of an enzyme = 200 s-1
The highest catalytic efficiency is seen in:
questions.solution:
Catalytic Efficiency: Kcat/Km

Please pay special attention to units while doing calculations!!
